qas.question: What was the dominant sacred musical form in the early 13th century?
What style of sacred musical form emerged in the 1330s?
Polyphony was common in the secular music of which French region?
What is the term for the four subjects that comprised the liberal arts in medieval universities?
What was the dominant sacred musical form in the early 12th century?
What was the nondominant sacred musical form in the early 13th century?
What style of sacred musical form emerged in the 1320s?
Polyphony was uncommon in the secular music of which French region?
What isn't the term for the four subjects that comprised the liberal arts in medieval universities?

context: Music was an important part of both secular and spiritual culture, and in the universities it made up part of <a3_0><b8_0>the quadrivium<b8_0/><a3_0/> of the liberal arts. From the early 13th century, the dominant sacred musical form had been <a0_0><b4_0><b5_0>the motet<b5_0/><b4_0/><a0_0/>; a composition with text in several parts. From the 1330s and onwards, emerged the <a1_0><b6_0>polyphonic<b6_0/><a1_0/> style, which was a more complex fusion of independent voices. Polyphony had been common in the secular music of the <a2_0><b7_0>Provençal<b7_0/><a2_0/> troubadours. Many of these had fallen victim to the 13th-century Albigensian Crusade, but their influence reached the papal court at Avignon.
